Dave,

I have 50 or so converged laminar flame cases in Chemkin II Premix, =
most for
the experiments from the literature. Fuels are from methane to ben=
zene,
low-p to atmospheric, simulated with a few detailed kinetic models fr=
om the
literature and with two of my own, ranging from 100 to 1200 reaction=
s. (200
or so runs in total). All the flames have temperature profile from =
the
experiment. That's kind of a lot for the e-mail attachment.

For about =
a third of those runs I have cantera solution as well, all with
multicompon=
ent diffusion. Differences between cantera and CK Premix
solutions are  in =
most cases negligible. In few cases I examined in detail,
the differences o=
riginate from your improvenments in diffusion formulation.

To my experienc=
e, Cantera (my Python premixed script) handles many a case on
which CK Prem=
ix gives up, but I have a handfull of cases that neither code
could find a =
solution for.

Which address would you like the stuff sent to? I e-mailed y=
ou one of my
premixed Python/Cantera scripts to 'dgoodwin@...' on M=
ay 11, but I
never heard back from you...

Sincerely,
            Zoran



=
I am interested in doing some validation tests of the flame models in 
Cant=
era, and would like to ask the assistance of anyone who routinely 
runs fla=
me simulations with the Chemkin version 2 codes PREMIX and/or 
OPPDIFF.  Wh=
at I am looking for are any converged, resolved flame 
solutions from Chemk=
in 2, including:

1) PREMIX or OPPDIFF input files
2) reaction mechanism an=
d thermo data files in Chemkin format
3) computed species and temperature p=
rofiles in some text file format

I am particularly interested in non-trivi=
al flames with large 
mechanisms or at atmospheric pressure or above (but a=
ny flame is 
useful).  I would also like to have examples both with mixture=
-averaged 
and multicomponent diffusion.  If you have this information for =
some 
flame or flames, please send me a tar or zip file with the files list=
ed 
above.  I will take this information, generate the corresponding 
Cante=
ra input files + python script, and compare the computed profiles 
(unless =
you want to do that too...).  I would plan on then sending back 
to you the=
 Cantera files, so that you could run a Cantera vs. Chemkin 2 
timing compa=
rison on the same machine.

Based on previous comparisons of thermo propert=
ies, transport 
properties, and kinetic rates, I fully expect excellent agr=
eement in 
the steady-state flame profiles, with substantial improvement in=
 
performance.  But a head-to-head flame comparison would be very 
interest=
ing, and would provide assurance to users converting from the 
Chemkin 2 co=
des that Cantera produces the same output, given the same 
input.

This wil=
l be most useful if we can get at least several flames from 
different grou=
ps, running on different machines, etc.
If you have been wanting to contrib=
ute to the development of Cantera 
and its acceptance by the combustion com=
munity, but aren't an expert in 
C++/Python, etc., here's a good opportunit=
y to do so!

Dave
